questions.text: A child presents with a history of fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. On examination of the oral cavity, the tonsil was found to be enlarged with beads of pus on its surface. What is the correct diagnosis for this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the description given, the most probable diagnosis is Acute follicular tonsillitis

  • Most common in school-going children
  • Hemolytic streptococcusis the most common infecting organism
  • Presents with fever, sore throat, dysphagia, earache, and constitutional symptoms.
  • On examination: Tonsils enlarged with multiple beads of pus on the surface

Clinical Features:

  • Sudden onset of sore throat and fever
  • Dysphagia (pain on swallowing)
  • Halitosis
  • Muffled voice
  • Tender jugulodigastric lymphadenopathy
  • On exam: Enlarged, hyperemic tonsils with multiple white/yellow spots (follicles)
  • No membrane (helps differentiate from diphtheria)

Acute tonsillitis is classified into

  • Acute catarrhal or superficial tonsillitis- Here, tonsillitis is a part of generalized pharyngitis and is mostly seen in viral infections. The mildest form involves only the mucous membrane of the tonsil. Tonsils appear red and congested, but no pus is visible. No white or yellow spots on the surface( Option A ruled out)
  • Acute follicular tonsillitis- Infection spreads into the crypts, which become filled with purulent material, presenting at the openings of crypts as yellowish spots
  • Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis- Here tonsil substance is affected. The tonsil is uniformly enlarged and red. Involves the deeper substance of the tonsil (the parenchyma). Tonsils are diffusely swollen, red, and tender, but no visible pus spots. Often associated with follicular type but not described by beads of pus( Option C ruled out)
  • Acute membranous tonsillitis - It is a stage ahead of acute follicular tonsillitis when exudation from the crypts coalesces to form a membrane on the surface of the tonsil. Tonsils are covered by a grayish-white membrane, which may resemble The membrane may bleed on removal. Not described as beads of pus, more of a sheet or membrane( Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A child 5 year old patient is scheduled for tonsillectomy. On the day of surgery, he had a runny nose, a temperature of 37.5 °C, and a dry cough. Which of the following should be the most appropriate decision for surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis, is a contraindication to tonsillectomy. Bleeding is more likely in the presence of acute infection.

Contraindications to tonsillectomy

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10 g/L.
  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract
  • Children under 3 years of age.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g., leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia, haemophilia, or sickle cell disease, von Willebrand disease.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g., diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Avoided during the period of menses

Explanation of Other Options:

Surgery should be cancelled(Option A):  This option suggests stopping the surgery but does not clarify for how long or what should be done in the meantime (e.g., treatment or rescheduling), making it incomplete and non-specific.

Can proceed with surgery if the chest is clear and there is no history of asthma(Option B): Although this may apply in older children or adults, it is not safe in a 5-year-old with URTI symptoms, as airway hyperreactivity still poses a risk even if the chest is clear and there's no asthma history.

Should get X-ray chest before proceeding with surgery(Option C): A chest X-ray is not routinely required in children with mild URTI symptoms unless there's suspicion of pneumonia. Also, a clear X-ray does not rule out perioperative airway complications from an upper respiratory tract infection.

choices.text: Adenoidectomy with Myringotomy with grommet insertion

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the hospital with a history of mouth breathing, malocclusion of teeth, and conductive hearing loss due to glue ear. Which of the following will be the best management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 6-year-old child presents with:

  • Mouth breathing suggests adenoidal hypertrophy
  • Malocclusion of teeth and chronic mouth breathing can affect facial bone development
  • Conductive hearing loss with glue ear (otitis media with effusion), commonly due to eustachian tube dysfunction caused by enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharyngeal opening

Best Management:

  • Adenoidectomy: Removes the obstructive adenoidal tissue, improving nasal breathing and eustachian tube function
  • Myringotomy: A small incision in the tympanic membrane to drain the fluid in glue ear
  • Grommet Insertion (ventilation tube): Maintains aeration of the middle ear and prevents reaccumulation of fluid

Explanation of Other Options:

Adenoidectomy(Option A): Adenoidectomy doesn't address the middle ear effusion.

Myringotomy(Option B): Myringotomy, temporary relief; doesn't treat the underlying adenoidal obstruction.

Adenoidectomy + Myringotomy(Option C): without grommet, high chance of recurrence of effusion.

choices.text: No lymph node enlargement as lymph nodes are only involved during acute attacks

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent tonsillitis presents to the clinic for elective tonsillectomy. He does not have any symptoms now. While examining the patient, which of the following would you find?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of chronic tonsillitis.
  • Enlargement of jugulodigastric lymph nodesis a reliable sign of chronic tonsillitis.
  • The jugulodigastric lymph node is the principal draining node of the palatine tonsil.
  • During acute attacks, the nodes enlarge further and become tender.

Other features of chronic tonsillitis include

  • Tonsils may show varying degrees of enlargement. Sometimes they meet in the midline(chronic parenchymatous type).
  • There may be yellowish beads of pus on the medial surface of the tonsil(chronic follicular type).
  • Tonsils are small, but pressure on the anterior pillar expresses frank pus or cheesy material(chronic fibroid type).
  • Flushing of the anterior pillarscompared to the rest of the pharyngeal mucosa.
  • Halitosis

Lymphatic Drainage of the Palatine Tonsils

  • Primary (Direct) Drainage: Jugulodigastric lymph node, also known as the tonsillar node
  • Secondary Drainage Pathway: Upper deep cervical nodes, Jugulo-omohyoid nodes

Explanation of Other Options:

Enlarged submental nodes(Option A): Drain anterior mouth (lip, floor of mouth), not tonsils.

Enlarged supraclavicular nodes(Option B): Associated with thoracic/abdominal malignancies, not tonsillar disease.

No lymph node enlargement(Option C): Chronic or recurrent infections can lead to persistent lymph node enlargement.

questions.text: All of the following are Relative contraindications of Adenoidectomy except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eustachian tube dysfunction is not a contraindication for adenoidectomy.

Contraindications of Adenoidectomy

  • Hemorrhagic disorders(Option C ruled out)
  • Cleft palate or submucous palate - Removal of adenoids causes velopharyngeal insufficiencyin such cases. (Option A ruled out)
  • Bifid uvula
  • Hypernasality(Option B ruled out)
  • Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract.

Indications of adenoidectomy:

  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion is associated with adenoid hyperplasia
  • Dental malocclusion
  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnea syndrome, or speech abnormalities

questions.text: A 7-year-old child undergoes tonsillectomy for recurrent tonsillitis. During dissection, bleeding is noted deep in the tonsillar fossa. Knowledge of the anatomical structures closely related to the bed of the tonsil is essential to prevent complications. All of the following are closely related to the bed of the tonsil except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The palatopharyngeus muscle does not form the bed of the tonsil.

Bed of the tonsil bed

  • Formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles. (Option B ruled out)
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve and styloid process, if enlarged, may lie within the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Both these structures can be surgically approached through the tonsillar bed after tonsillectomy.
  • The internal carotid arterylies one inch lateral to the tonsillar bed

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is diagnosed with adenoid hypertrophy presenting as nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and sleep-disordered breathing. Surgical adenoidectomy is planned..Which of the following is not a method for adenoidectomy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Coblation, Microdebrider, and Suction diathermy are the newer methods of adenoidectomy
  • The dissection and Snaremethod is used for;tonsillectomy.
  • The traditional method for adenoidectomy is curettage, which is a blind procedure using a St clare Thompson curette

Explanation of Other Options:

Coblation (Option A): Uses radiofrequency energy in a saline medium to ablate tissue at low temperature (~60-70°C). Minimally invasive, less bleeding, and less postoperative pain. Commonly used in modern adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy.

Microdebrider (Option B): A powered instrument with a rotating blade and suction. Provides precise tissue removal under endoscopic guidance. Useful for revision surgeries or adenoids near the Eustachian tube.

Suction diathermy (Option C): Combines suction and electrocautery to remove and coagulate adenoidal tissue. Minimizes intraoperative bleeding. Widely used under endoscopic or mirror guidance.

choices.text: The extracapsular approach is best for cold surgery
Sleep apnea with large tonsils is an indication
Adenoids should also be removed if significantly enlarged
In Rose's position, the neck is placed in flexion.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for elective tonsillectomy due to recurrent tonsillitis. Regarding tonsillectomy in children, which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rose's position:

  • The patient lies supine with the neck extendedby placing a pillow under the shoulders. A rubber ring is placed under the head to stabilize it.
  • Hyperextension should always be avoided.
  • Used for adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy.

Barking dog position:

  • The patient lies supine. The head is elevated by 10-15 cm by placing a pillow under the occiput. The neck is flexedon the thorax, and the head is extended on the atlanto-occipital joint.
  • Brings the mouth, pharynx, and oesophagus into a straight line.
  • Used for direct laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, oesophagoscopy.

Absolute Indications for Tonsillectomy

  • Recurrent Acute Tonsillitis
    • 7 or more episodes in 1 year
    • 5 episodes per year for 2 consecutive years
    • Due to adenotonsillar hypertrophy causing snoring, restless sleep, apneic episodes, or failure to thrive.
  • Peritonsillar Abscess (Quinsy) - Recurrent or unresponsive to drainage.
  • Suspicion or Diagnosis of Tonsillar Malignancy
    • Especially in asymmetrical tonsil enlargement with cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Chronic Tonsillitis Unresponsive to Medical Therapy

Relative Indications for Tonsillectomy

  • Chronic Bad Breath (Halitosis): Due to tonsilloliths or chronic cryptic tonsillitis.
  • Recurrent Febrile Seizures Associated with Tonsillitis
    • Especially in young children with poorly controlled fever episodes.
  • Persistent Cervical Lymphadenitis: Due to chronic tonsillar infection.
  • Difficulty Swallowing or Speech Abnormalities: Due to gross tonsillar hypertrophy.
  • Tonsilloliths – Recurrent or symptomatic (foul taste, pain, or foreign body sensation).
  • Otitis Media with Effusion (OME): In cases of adenotonsillar hypertrophy causing Eustachian tube dysfunction (often done as adenoidectomy + tonsillectomy).

Explanation of Other Options:

The extracapsular technique is the preferred approach in cold dissection tonsillectomy (Option A):

  • Cold dissection (cold steel) tonsillectomy uses a scalpel and dissectors to remove the tonsil extracapsular(removing the tonsil along with its capsule).
  • This is the traditional and preferred method for cold surgery.
  • Helps in reducing postoperative bleeding when done carefully.

Obstructive sleep apnea due to enlarged tonsils is a valid indication(Option B):

  • OSA (Obstructive Sleep Apnea) in children is a major indication for adenotonsillectomy.
  • It is often caused by adenotonsillar hypertrophy, especially in children without frequent infections.

Enlarged adenoids should be removed concurrently if significantly hypertrophied (Option C):

  • If adenoids are significantly enlarged, especially with nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, or recurrent otitis media, adenotonsillectomy is preferred.
  • This ensures better airway patency and reduced recurrence of symptoms.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is scheduled for a tonsillectomy due to recurrent infections. Various surgical tools and techniques are available for performing tonsillectomy. All of the following are used for tonsillectomy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Suction diathermy is a method of adenoidectomy.

Suction diathermy combines suction with bipolar or monopolar electrocautery.

It is a surgical instrument that combines suction (to clear blood and secretions) with electrocautery (diathermy) to cut tissue and coagulate bleeding vessels simultaneously.

Advantages:

  • Minimal intraoperative bleeding due to simultaneous coagulation
  • Better visibility (because suction clears the field)
  • Reduced operative time
  • Useful in patients with bleeding tendencies or in children

Others are newer methods of tonsillectomy:

The main advantage of these methods is less blood loss

Newer methods in Adenoidectomy:

  • Coblation-controlled cold ablation, which reduces thermal damage and postoperative pain.
  • Suction diathermy- Combines suction with bipolar or monopolar electrocautery.
  • microdebrider- combined rotatory blade and suction, leading to tissue shaving

choices.text: Physiological enlargement continues up to 6 years of age
Adenoids do not have a capsule
Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding adenoids is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Before adenoidectomy, the adenoid mass should always be palpated before surgery to:

  • Confirm the diagnosis
  • To rule out any abnormal vessel overlying the adenoid mass.

The adenoid is irregular on palpation, like a bag of worms.

Traditionally, in conventional adenoidectomy, digital palpation is performed after the child is under general anesthesia.

  • This is done to:
    • Assess the size and consistency of the adenoid tissue
    • Check for any asymmetry, cysts, or masses
    • Plan the extent of curettage required
  • Endoscopic adenoidectomy is increasingly replacing blind curettage, but digital palpation is still considered a valuable step if endoscopy is not available.

Clinical Note:

  • Some surgeons may avoid digital palpation if malignancy is suspected, but in routine adenoidectomy for benign hypertrophy, it is standard practice.

Explanation of Other Options:

Physiological enlargement continues up to 6 years of age(Option A): Adenoids normally enlarge up to 5-6 years as part of normal immune development. They then involute during adolescence.

Adenoids do not have a capsule (Option B): Unlike palatine tonsils, adenoids are not encapsulated. They are part of Waldeyer's ring, situated in the nasopharynx.

Adenoids do not have crypts(Option C): Palatine tonsils have crypts; adenoids do not. Adenoid surface is smooth or lobulated but lacks crypt-like invaginations.

choices.text: Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch from the Maxillary artery

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is scheduled for a tonsillectomy due to recurrent tonsillitis. During the procedure, brisk bleeding is encountered from the tonsillar bed. Which artery provides the primary blood supply to the palatine tonsil?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The primary blood supply to the palatine tonsil is from the Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

Blood supply of the tonsil

All of these are branches of the External Carotid Artery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ascending pharyngeal artery(Option A):

  • A branch of the external carotid artery.
  • It gives pharyngeal branches that supply the superior part of the pharynx and contribute to the tonsillar vascular supply.
  • However, it is not the primary

Dorsal lingual branches of lingual artery(Option B):

  • The lingual artery, another external carotid branch, gives dorsal lingual branches.
  • These supply the posterior part of the tongue and contribute minimally to the tonsillar region.

Descending palatine branch from maxillary artery(Option D):

  • A branch of the maxillary artery (external carotid system).
  • The greater palatine artery, a branch of the descending palatine artery, supplies the hard palate and adjacent areas.
  • It may send small branches to the tonsillar area, but it is not the main source.
